questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous veins in the leg. He had a history of trauma 10 years back in the same limb. On examination, the dilated tortuous vein showed pulsatility. Most likely diagnosis in this patient will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AV fistula

 

An arteriovenous (AV) fistula is an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein. The history of trauma in the same limb suggests a possible traumatic AV fistula. The presence of pulsatility in the veins is a key indicator, as it implies that arterial pressure is being transmitted to the veins. This is not typical for varicose veins, aneurysms, or hemangiomas, making AV fistula the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicose vein: Varicose veins are typically dilated, tortuous veins caused by incompetent valves but do not show pulsatility.

 

Option B. Aneurysm: Aneurysms involve arterial dilation and do not present with pulsatile veins.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors of blood vessels, usually presenting as a mass and not associated with pulsatile veins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of trauma with the presence of dilated tortuous veins showing pulsatility strongly indicates an arteriovenous fistula due to the transmission of arterial pulsation to the veins

questions.text: Kaposi sarcoma present in Which CD4 count? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) <500

 

Kaposi's sarcoma is a common opportunistic infection associated with HIV infection. It typically presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells per cubic millimeter. Kaposi's sarcoma is a type of cancer that forms in the lining of blood and lymph vessels. The exact CD4 count at which Kaposi's sarcoma presents can vary, but it is generally observed in patients with moderately suppressed immune systems, which corresponds to a CD4 count of less than 500 cells/mm³.

 

Graph showing the Opportunistic infections associated with HIV infections and correlation with CD4 T cells counts.

 

 

When the CD4 count is at 500, individuals might also face bacterial skin infections, HSV, and fungal infections. As the CD4 count drops further, other infections like hairy leukoplakia and tuberculosis (at CD4 < 400), PCP, Cryptococcus, and Toxoplasmosis (at CD4 < 200), and infections like MAC, CMV, and lymphoma (at CD4 < 50) can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi's sarcoma in HIV patients generally presents when the CD4 count drops below 500 cells/mm³.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with painful oral mucosal lesions and blisters on her skin. A biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence microscopy is used to examine the skin specimen. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by painful mucosal lesions and skin blisters.

 

The direct immunofluorescence (DIF) image shows a characteristic "fishnet" or "chicken-wire" pattern due to IgG antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3, which are components of the desmosomes that connect epidermal cells.

 

The disruption of these desmosomes leads to acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation, as seen in pemphigus vulgaris. The presence of painful oral lesions further supports this diagnosis, as they are commonly seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: This condition also presents with blisters but typically in older patients without mucosal involvement. DIF shows a linear pattern of IgG and C3 at the basement membrane zone, not the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is characterized by intensely pruritic vesicles and papules, typically on extensor surfaces. DIF shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, which is different from the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D. Lupus vulgaris: This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting with slow-growing reddish-brown nodules, not blisters. It does not show a fishnet pattern on DIF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris presents with painful oral lesions and skin blisters, and its hallmark DIF finding is the fishnet pattern due to antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3.

questions.text: Leading questions are permitted during which kind of examination in court? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cross examination 

 

  • Leading questions in law are questions asked by an attorney, to a witness, with the goal of "putting words in the mouth of the witness," to achieve a desired response or result.
  • Answer to leading question can be given in “yes” or “No”
  • Example:
    • Has Ram killed shyam? It is a leading question.
    • Who has killed shyam? It is not a leading question
  • IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA (Indian Evidence Act).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Examination-in-chief: Leading questions are generally not allowed during examination-in-chief to prevent the lawyer from influencing the witness's testimony.

 

Option B. Direct examination: Similar to examination-in-chief, direct examination aims to elicit the witness's own account without leading questions.

 

Option D. Re-direct examination: Leading questions are also not allowed in re-direct examination, as the purpose is to clarify or rebut points raised during cross-examination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in: 

  1. Examination in chief
  2. Re-Examination
  3. Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in: 

  1. Cross Examination
  2. Dying Deposition
  3. Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief

questions.text: Which tendons are involved in the test shown below?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) APL and EPB

 

  • Finkelstein test has been shown which helps to diagnose de Quervain’s tenosynovitis (Inflammation of Abductor Pollicis Longus and Extensor Pollicis brevis).

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic.
  • The examiner places patients’ thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction.
  • In positive test, this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the thumb left free is relatively painless.

 

 

  • Differential diagnosis includes scaphoid non-union, arthritis at the base of thumb and intersection syndrome.
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons are inflamed in the condition called De Quervain Tenosynovitis.
  • The diagnostic special test for the condition is called Finkelstein Test as shown in the image in the question.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from height. The patient reports no pain or injury, but on examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. The patient is hemodynamically stable with no other injuries. The next step in management would be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ascending urethrogram

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests a suspected urethral injury with blood at the urethral meatus, which is commonly caused by external trauma or instrumentation.
  •  To confirm urethral rupture, the next step would be an ascending urethrogram.
  • Ascending urethrogram: Correct. In a patient who is hemodynamically stable and without symptoms of a full bladder, retrograde urethrography will help determine the extent of the injury and decide on the next appropriate steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheterization: In the setting of suspected urethral injury, as evidenced by the presence of blood at the tip of the urethral meatus, inserting a Foley catheter can be harmful. It could potentially exacerbate the injury or convert a partial tear into a complete one. Hence, this is contraindicated without first confirming the integrity of the urethra.

 

Option C. Nephrogram: A nephrogram is an imaging study of the kidneys and their function. While it can give details about the upper urinary tract, it's not typically used for evaluating urethral injuries.

 

Option D. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy, or suprapubic catheter placement, involves inserting a catheter directly into the bladder through the abdominal wall. It's done to divert urine when urethral catheterization is not possible or contraindicated, such as in the setting of a known or suspected urethral injury. This will be attempted after an urethrogram confirms a rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management.
  • Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury from the picture given below: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incised looking lacerated wound

 

The image shows a lacerated wound which looks like incised wound. This is also called “Incised looking lacerated wound”. They occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

They can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:

 

  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laceration: Irregular tear-like wounds caused by blunt trauma. They often have jagged edges and may have tissue bridges at the base. The wound in the image appears cleaner and more linear, resembling an incised wound, making it an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Option B. Incised wound: Clean, straight cuts typically caused by sharp instruments such as knives or glass. The wound in the image is caused by blunt force and has characteristics of a laceration, despite its appearance.

 

Option C. Lacerated looking incised wound:  In areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc, the shapes are zigzag type. So, although it is produced by sharp weapon but it looks like lacerated wound. Such wounds are sometimes called as lacerated looking incised wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An incised looking lacerated wound is caused by blunt force trauma but appears similar to an incised wound due to its location and the characteristics of the tissue involved.

choices.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period

questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

 

Explanation:

 

The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.

 

 

AT POINT 1 - Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.

 

AT POINT 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens à Na+ flows inward.

 

AT POINT 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.

 

AT POINT 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.

 

Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.

 

The refractory period is divided into two, an absolute refractory period and a relative refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Threshold potential is reached just before point B where a rapid depolarization phase begins.

 

Option B: Incorrect. At point E, the nerve is not more excitable; rather, it is in a hyperpolarized state where more than the normal stimulus would be needed to generate another action potential.

 

Option C: Incorrect. The transition from C to D is characterized by the closing of Na+ channels and the opening of K+ channels, not the other way around.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phases of an action potential -

 

  • Point A: Represents the resting membrane potential.
  • Point B: Marks the threshold potential.

 

Point C: Represents the peak of the action potential.

 

  • Point D: Repolarization phase
  • Point E: Hyperpolarization phase
  • Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C
  • Relative refractory period from around point C to D

questions.text: What is the distance from the upper incisor teeth to the bronchial constriction of the esophagus? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer. C. 27 cm

 

Explanation:

 

The bronchial constriction of the esophagus occurs at the level where the left main bronchus crosses the esophagus, which is approximately 27 cm (11 inches) from the upper incisor teeth. This constriction is located at the T6 vertebral level. The esophagus has four sites of constriction: the cervical constriction at the cricopharyngeal junction (C6), the aortic constriction where the aortic arch crosses (T4), the bronchial constriction at the left main bronchus (T6), and the diaphragmatic constriction at the esophageal hiatus (T10). These constrictions are important to consider during endoscopic procedures or when evaluating patients with dysphagia.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 15 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the cervical constriction at the cricopharyngeal junction.

 

Option B. 22 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the aortic constriction where the aortic arch crosses the esophagus.

 

Option D. 40 cm - Incorrect. This distance corresponds to the diaphragmatic constriction at the esophageal hiatus.

 

Educational objective:

 

The bronchial constriction of the esophagus lies 27 cm (11 inches) from the upper incisor teeth, at the level where the left main bronchus crosses the esophagus (T6 vertebral level).

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program to a 10-year-old school child? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td

 

  • Based on the situation provided, a ten-year-old student is recommended to receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.
  • The Td vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen, and is recommended for older children and adults.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) advises the use of Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is injected into the upper arm muscle. This vaccine is given at the age of 10 and 16.
  • For pregnant women, Td-1 is given early in pregnancy and Td-2 is given 4 weeks after Td-1. A Td booster shot is recommended if a pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were previously received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: Which of the following is the best test for long-term control of diabetes? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HbA1C

 

HbA1C, also known as glycated hemoglobin, is the best test for assessing long-term control of diabetes. It reflects the average blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 3 months. This is because the lifespan of a red blood cell (RBC) is approximately 90 to 120 days, and HbA1C measures the percentage of hemoglobin that is glycated (coated with sugar). Therefore, it provides a comprehensive view of a patient's blood glucose control over a longer period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycated Albumin: Glycated albumin reflects blood glucose control over a shorter period, typically the last 2 to 3 weeks. While it can be useful in certain situations, it does not provide as long-term a view as HbA1C.

 

Option C. Urine sugar: Measuring sugar in the urine is not a reliable method for assessing long-term glucose control. It only indicates that the blood glucose level has been high enough to spill over into the urine, which reflects immediate/ recent glucose levels.

 

Option D. Fasting blood sugar: Fasting blood sugar provides information about the blood glucose level at a single point in time, typically after an overnight fast. It is useful for diagnosing diabetes and assessing short-term control but does not reflect long-term glucose control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HbA1C is the best test for evaluating long-term control of diabetes, providing an average of blood glucose levels over the past 2 to 3 months.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelium

 

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration/deturgescence level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea deturgescent, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

 

The different layers of cornea:

 

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. Bowman’s membrane cannot regenerate after corneal surgery.
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - Consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans.
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - Consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - Consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descemet's membrane: Provides structural support but does not actively maintain corneal deturgescence.

 

Option C. Stroma: Contains collagen fibrils essential for structural integrity and transparency, but its hydration is controlled by the endothelium.

 

Option D. Corneal epithelium: Acts as a barrier to infection and injury but does not play a primary role in maintaining corneal hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

choices.text: Elemental calcium of 1200mg/ day is recommended
Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium
Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered
Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

questions.text: A 60-year post-menopausal obese lady presents with backache. She has a history of Colle’s fracture 1 year back. A DEXA scan shows a T score of less than - 2.5. Which of the following is false? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year

 

Explanation:

 

Management of Osteoporosis:

 

  • Elemental Calcium and Vitamin D:
    • Postmenopausal women are recommended to take 1200 mg/day of elemental calcium along with 400-800 IU of vitamin D to help maintain bone health and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • Bisphosphonates:
    • Bisphosphonates such as Alendronate, Risedronate, Ibandronate, and Zoledronic acid are commonly used to treat osteoporosis. These drugs help to slow down bone resorption, thus preserving bone density.
    • The recommended duration of bisphosphonate therapy is generally 3-5 years, not limited to just 1 year. Studies have shown that longer-term use of bisphosphonates can continue to provide benefits in reducing the risk of fractures. However, the exact duration should be individualized based on the patient's risk factors and response to treatment.
  • Teriparatide:
    • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone that stimulates new bone formation. It is particularly beneficial in patients with severe osteoporosis or those who have not responded well to bisphosphonates.
    • When considering treatment with both teriparatide and bisphosphonates, it is often recommended to start with teriparatide first to build bone and then follow with bisphosphonates to maintain the bone density gains achieved with teriparatide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elemental calcium of 1200mg/day is recommended: This statement is true. Adequate calcium intake is essential for bone health, especially in postmenopausal women.

 

Option B. Oral vit D3 is to be given with calcium: This statement is true. Vitamin D3 helps in the absorption of calcium and is recommended to be given along with calcium supplements.

 

Option C. Teriparatide is to be started first if treatment with teriparatide and bisphosphonates is being considered: This statement is true. Starting with teriparatide helps build bone density, and following with bisphosphonates helps maintain the gains.

 

Option D. Bisphosphonates should not be given for more than 1 year: This statement is false. Bisphosphonates can be given for a longer duration, typically 3-5 years, depending on the patient's individual risk factors and response to therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are typically recommended for a duration of 3-5 years in the treatment of osteoporosis, not limited to just 1 year.

 

Ref: Page no 500, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

The described clinical picture is consistent with Delirium tremens (DT). DT is a severe and potentially life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal. It typically appears 48 to 72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by agitation, disorientation, paranoid delusions, tremors, autonomic hyperactivity (such as tachycardia and hypertension), and visual or tactile hallucinations. It can be fatal if not treated promptly and properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's encephalopathy: It is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics. Symptoms include ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis: It is a chronic neurologic sequelae of alcoholism resulting from prolonged thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and lack of insight.

 

Option D. Alcohol-induced psychosis: It is a rare complication where patients present with hallucinations after heavy, prolonged alcohol consumption but without other features of withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: As per the latest MTP act, termination of failed contraception is allowed till which weeks of contraception? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20 weeks

 

The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act allows for the termination of pregnancy under specific conditions. For failed contraception, termination is permitted up to 20 weeks of pregnancy. This is because the law recognizes that contraceptive failure can occur, and it allows individuals the right to terminate the pregnancy within this timeframe.

 

Note –

 

  • Termination up to 24 weeks is only allowed under specific conditions such as rape, fetal anomalies, or if the woman is disabled.
  • Termination beyond 24 weeks is only permitted in cases of congenital anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MTP Act permits termination of pregnancy due to failed contraception up to 20 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following IV anesthetics acts on an NMDA receptor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketamine

 

Ketamine is an intravenous anesthetic that acts as an antagonist at the NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor. NMDA receptors are involved in the excitatory neurotransmission in the brain, particularly in the processes of synaptic plasticity and memory function. Ketamine inhibits these receptors, leading to a dissociative anesthesia characterized by analgesia, amnesia, and altered sensory perception without complete loss of consciousness. This unique mechanism of action makes ketamine distinct from other commonly used IV anesthetics.

 

Note - The inhalational agents that act on the NMDA receptor as antagonists are xenon and nitrous oxide

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol acts primarily as a GABA agonist, enhancing the activity of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA at the GABA-A receptor, leading to sedation and anesthesia. It does not act on NMDA receptors.

 

Option C. Thiopentone sodium: Thiopentone, a barbiturate, also works as a GABA agonist, similar to propofol. It does not affect NMDA receptors.

 

Option D. Midazolam: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that acts on the GABA-A receptor as well, increasing the inhibitory effects of GABA. Like propofol and thiopentone, it does not interact with NMDA receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine is unique among IV anesthetics for its action as an NMDA receptor antagonist, leading to its characteristic dissociative anesthesia.

questions.text: In the shown image, which one of the following is a source of vitamin B1? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) is primarily found in whole grains, cereals, nuts, and legumes. The primary source of thiamine in grains is the aleurone layer, which is often removed during the polishing process of white rice. However, parboiling rice can help preserve this layer, retaining the vitamin B1 content. In the provided image, the food item labeled 'A' is rice, which is a source of vitamin B1, especially when not overly polished.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This option does not represent a significant source of vitamin B1. It appears to be a different food item that does not contain high levels of this vitamin.

 

Option C. The item labeled 'C' is not a grain or a food typically high in vitamin B1.

 

Option D. This option is also not a significant source of vitamin B1, as it does not represent a grain or similar food known for its thiamine content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B1 is primarily found in the aleurone layer of grains, which can be removed by polishing but is preserved in parboiled rice.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is in labor, and her cardiotocogram (CTG) is shown. What does this CTG indicate? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early decelerations

 

Early decelerations are characterized by:

 

  • When decelerations are in symmetry with the uterine contractions, the nadir corresponds to the peak of the contraction.
  • Early deceleration is seen when the head of the fetus is compressed in the second stage of the labor.
  • Early decelerations, specially in the second stage of the labor are normal

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variable decelerations: Incorrect

 

  • Variable decelerations are seen typically when the cord is getting compressed. There is no relation between the deceleration and the uterine contraction. 
    • Seen in Oligohydramnios. 

 

 

Option C. Late decelerations: Incorrect

 

  • The start, nadir and end of the deceleration occurs after the start, peak and end of the contraction
    • These are dangerous as this means that there is fetal distress 

 

 

Option D. Normal CTG: Incorrect

 

  • because while early decelerations are reassuring, they represent a variation from the normal baseline pattern
  • Normal CTG shows no consistent decelerations with contractions

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Early decelerations are characterized by symmetrical drops in fetal heart rate with the nadir coinciding with the peak of uterine contractions, caused by head compression during labor, and are considered physiological

questions.text: Which antibodies are characterized against Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desmoglein 1 and 3.

 

  • Mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris is characterized by antibodies against both Desmoglein 1 and Desmoglein 3. 

 

 

  • In Pemphigus vulgaris, the target antigens are "Desmoglein-3 > 1," which means both are involved but Desmoglein-3 is predominant. 
  • While mucosal-dominant PV has antibodies primarily against Desmoglein 3, mucocutaneous PV (affecting both skin and mucosa) requires antibodies to both Desmoglein 1 and 3. 
  • The presence of both antibodies explains the development of skin lesions in addition to oral involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desmoglein 1: 

 

  • This is primarily the target antigen in Pemphigus foliaceus. When only anti-Dsg1 antibodies are present, they cause skin lesions without mucosal involvement. 
  • Isolated anti-Dsg1 antibodies cannot explain the mucocutaneous manifestation of PV.

 

Option B. Desmoglein 3: 

 

  • While anti-Dsg3 antibodies are predominant in Pemphigus vulgaris, having only anti-Dsg3 antibodies typically results in mucosal-dominant disease. 
  • Mucocutaneous PV requires both anti-Dsg1 and anti-Dsg3 antibodies.

 

Option D. None: 

 

  • Incorrect as Pemphigus vulgaris definitely has autoantibodies against desmogleins. The absence of anti-desmoglein antibodies would be inconsistent with the diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mucocutaneous Pemphigus vulgaris requires antibodies against both Desmoglein 1 and 3, with Desmoglein-3 antibodies typically being predominant; this combined antibody profile explains the involvement of both skin and mucous membranes.

questions.text: Function of IL-8 is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Chemotaxis

 

Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a cytokine that primarily functions as a chemokine. It plays a crucial role in the immune response by attracting and activating neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation through chemotaxis. This movement of neutrophils to the affected area helps in fighting infections effectively, as they are key cells in the innate immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fever: Fever is primarily induced by cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-alpha, not IL-8. These cytokines act on the hypothalamus to increase body temperature, which is a part of the systemic inflammatory response.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte proliferation: Lymphocyte proliferation is mainly associated with cytokines such as IL-2, which stimulates the growth of T cells. IL-8 does not play a direct role in lymphocyte proliferation.

 

Option D. TH1 activation: TH1 activation is driven by cytokines like IL-12 and IFN-gamma, which promote the differentiation of T-helper cells into the TH1 subtype. IL-8 is not involved in this process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary function of IL-8 is to induce chemotaxis, particularly attracting neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation.

choices.text: Bone marrow aspirate
Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
Polymerase chain reaction

questions.text: A 62-year-old elderly male presented with persistent fatigue and lymph total leucocyte count of 50,000/µl. His peripheral smear was done and had the findings as shown. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

The given history of elderly male with leucocytosis and the peripheral smear showing “smudge cells” is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The diagnosis of CLL can be confirmed using flow cytometry demonstrating cells with CD5/CD23 expression.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow aspirate: While useful in some cases, it is not necessary for the initial diagnosis of CLL if flow cytometry can provide definitive results.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is useful for detecting specific genetic abnormalities but is not the first step in confirming CLL.

 

Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR can detect specific genetic mutations but is not typically used for the initial diagnosis of CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a suspected case of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), especially with the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear, flow cytometry is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

choices.text: Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume
Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve
Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption
Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with dyspnea and chest pain. Which of the following proves that she has aortic stenosis rather than aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume

 

In cases of aortic stenosis, the primary issue is the increased afterload due to the obstruction in the aortic valve, which forces the left ventricle to work harder to push blood against the increased resistance. This increased pressure work leads to higher myocardial oxygen consumption because the heart needs more energy to overcome the obstruction. The increase in pressure work (afterload) is significantly more in aortic stenosis than in aortic regurgitation, where volume overload (preload) is more prominent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve: This statement is incorrect because aortic stenosis actually increases the pressure at the aortic valve due to the obstruction, not reduces it.

 

Option C. Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption: This is incorrect. Myocardial oxygen consumption is directly related to the workload of the heart. Increased workload, especially due to pressure overload in conditions like aortic stenosis, results in higher oxygen consumption.

 

Option D. Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload: This is incorrect because in aortic stenosis, the afterload (pressure) is more significantly increased than the preload. Preload (end-diastolic volume) is typically increased in conditions like aortic regurgitation, not aortic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic stenosis is characterized by increased pressure work (afterload) leading to higher myocardial oxygen consumption, distinguishing it from aortic regurgitation, which is associated with volume overload (preload).

questions.text: Fatty acid transport through mitochondrial membrane is via? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine

 

Carnitine plays a crucial role in the transport of long-chain fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane for subsequent beta-oxidation. It forms a complex with fatty acids, allowing them to enter the mitochondria.

 

Fatty acid transport into mitochondria from cytoplasm involve the carnitine shuttle system using enzymes Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase-I (CPT-I) and CPT-II. CPT-I is RLE of fatty acid transport or beta-oxidation of fatty acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyl carrier protein: Acyl carrier proteins are involved in fatty acid synthesis rather than transport across the mitochondrial membrane. They are essential components of fatty acid biosynthesis pathways.

 

Option C. Cholesterol transporter: Cholesterol transporters primarily facilitate the transport of cholesterol, not fatty acids, across cellular membranes. They are not directly involved in fatty acid transport into mitochondria.

 

Option D. LCAT (Lecithin-Cholesterol Acyltransferase): LCAT is an enzyme responsible for esterifying cholesterol, and it does not play a role in fatty acid transport across the mitochondrial membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acid transport through the mitochondrial membrane involves the carnitine shuttle system. Long-chain fatty acids are activated to form fatty acyl-CoA in the cytoplasm. Carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT I) then catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming fatty acyl-carnitine.

 

Fatty acyl-carnitine is transported across the mitochondrial membrane via a carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase.Once inside the mitochondrial matrix, carnitine acyltransferase II (CAT II) catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group back to CoA, allowing the fatty acid to undergo β-oxidation.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 208

questions.text: A 50-year-old female undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer develops diffuse hair loss following the treatment. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anagen effluvium

 

This is a classic case of anagen effluvium where:

 

  • Hair loss occurs 3-4 weeks after chemotherapy/radiotherapy
  • Actively dividing anagen hair follicles (80-90% of scalp hair) are directly damaged
  • Complete destruction of anagen phase leads to diffuse hair loss
  • No conversion of anagen to telogen phase occurs
  • Loss is abrupt and extensive due to direct damage to growing follicles

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Telogen effluvium

 

  • Occurs 3 months after a stressful trigger (not immediately)
  • Triggers include surgery, pregnancy, infections like typhoid/dengue/COVID
  • Involves premature conversion of anagen to telogen phase
  • Not associated with direct follicular damage


 

Option C. Trichotillomania

 

  • Associated with psychiatric issues/OCD
  • Compulsive hair pulling disorder
  • Shows incomplete patch of hair loss with varying lengths
  • Not related to chemotherapy

 


Option D. Alopecia areata

 

  • Presents as well-defined patches of complete hair loss
  • Autoimmune targeting of anagen hair bulb
  • Shows exclamation mark hairs at margins
  • No association with chemotherapy


 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Chemotherapy-induced hair loss is due to anagen effluvium, where rapidly dividing hair follicle cells are damaged. 
  • Hair loss starts within weeks of chemotherapy initiation and is diffuse and non-scarring. 
  • Hair typically regrows within a few months after stopping chemotherapy.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis is associated with which type of cancer? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis, also known as the Chinese liver fluke, is a parasitic worm that infects the bile ducts of the liver. Chronic infection with Clonorchis sinensis is a well-known risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma, which is a type of cancer that occurs in the bile ducts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular cancer: This is commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B and C infections, cirrhosis, and aflatoxin exposure, not typically with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option C. Gastric cancer: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, dietary factors, and genetic predisposition, not with Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Option D. Urinary bladder cancer: Often linked to smoking, occupational exposures, and Schistosoma haematobium infection (another type of parasitic worm), not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Opisthorchis viverrini is the new name of Clonorchis sinensis. It is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Humans acquire the infection by eating raw or undercooked freshwater fish containing the metacercariae (infective stage).

 

Chronic infection leads to:

 

  • Inflammation
  • Hyperplasia of the biliary epithelium
  • Fibrosis
  • Malignant transformation → Cholangiocarcinoma
